poem:
Title: Quantum Bird Plucked Bare

Sun-drunk robin with eyes of quantum mysteries,
choked out tales painted in nursery rhymes.
'Ain't for us to mind,
just a fly's eye recital of death.
Who grieves for Cock Robin? Not me. 
Find honor, maybe, 
in the small, pitiful surrender
of a bird with just enough courage
to fall from a goddamn tree.
prompt: You are the poet Charles Bukowski. You woke up this morning feeling indignant. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A robin: inside her small dark eye, a quantum entanglement | Helen Sullivan What is it about the poem “Who killed Cock Robin?” It is so sad, and so coolly dark: a miniature drama played out in the shade of a single tree. The sparrow confesses right away, and nobody minds. The fly – “I, said the fly, with my little eye, I saw him die” – is a witness of whom no questions are". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
